resources.string: Private key exported in UNCIPHERED form!
Please do not leave passphrase blank
Please do not leave Common name blank
{0,choice,0#No certificate requests|1#One certificate request|1<{0} certificate requests}
{0,choice,0#No records|1#One record|1<{0} records} imported or affected
Select file to sign or verify
Are you SURE you want to remove certificate {0}?
Are you SURE you want to remove certificate request {0}?
Are you SURE you want to remove all keys, certificates and requests in this record?
Are you 100% positive? You are going to loose all keys and certificates in this record!
Please set archive directory in settings
Please set archive passphrase in settings
Validity end must not precede validity begin
{0,choice,0#No revoked certificates|1#One revoked certificate|1<{0} revoked certificates}
Are you SURE you want to revoke certificate {0}?
Are you SURE you want to un-revoke certificate {0}?

You are using free Trial version of YOCA PKI application. This differs from full-featured version in:
• validity of issued certificates is limited to 7 days
• organization name is fixed to predefined text

Archive your data after every change. Archive file (*.yoca) is AES encrypted ZIP stream containing all managed objects such as keys, certificates and CSR\'s. Please set encryption passphrase in application settings before first archiving. Same passphrase must be set on every device where you need to restore data from archived file.

With this tool you can create key-pair with single self-signed authority certificate. You need to specify at least new record name, private key passphrase and certificate "Common name". Authority certificates usually contain text "ROOT CA" in their Common names. Consider validity length for all other certificates signed with this authority became invalid after expiration of this certificate. Use strong passphrase to protect authority private key. Some security tools may not accept SHA-256 signature.
With this tool you can generate new key-pair in new record. No certificate is created at this moment.

This tool lets you issue new certificate request (CSR) which can be submitted to any certification authority for signing. You can sign issued CSR with any authority managed by this application as well. CSR is public key plus requested subject name (common name, organization, locality, etc.) signed with corresponding private key. This ensures potential receiver that public key inside this CSR was not tampered during its transmission.

Take extra care of \"Common name\" field:
• in case you are issuing new HTTPS server certificate you need to enter fully qualified domain name, such as \"www.mydomain.com\", otherwise web browsers will not accept your certificate
• in case you are issuing certificate for HTTPS client authentication or VPN authentication, you will probably need to specify there some kind of unique client ID, such as login name

PKCS#12 bundle is standard container format for holding objects such as keys and certificates. Typically you can use this to import private key and certificate into web browser and use them as client authentication for HTTPS services.
Record contains always public key and optionally private key. Record also groups together all issued certificates and certification requests sharing the same public key.

All objects managed by this application are kept in private filesystem space, which ensures no other application can reach them (on non-rooted devices). Unfortunately it also means that all data are wiped out when you uninstall this application. Therefore you are encouraged to ARCHIVE YOUR DATA OFTEN so that accidental uninstallation would not cause data loss.

Please send comments and bug reports by clicking About application item in the Settings menu.

This application contains set of tools for asymmetric cryptography. Asymmetric cryptography uses two mathematically linked keys. Only way to decrypt data encrypted with one of them is to use the other one. One of them is declared public and is usually used for data encryption and verifying signatures. The other is declared private, protected with passphrase and is used for decryption and creating data signatures.

Signature is data digest encrypted with private key. Only way to verify signature is to decrypt signature with corresponding public key and compare the result with computed data digest. It serves to ensure receiver that data were not tampered during its transmission from sender. Digest is short fixed-length \"fingerprint\" of large data which changes rapidly with even the slightest change of data (eg. change of single bit).

This screen contains informations about issued or imported certificate signing request (CSR). CSR can be submitted to any certification authority to sign. You can also sign CSR with any authority with private key managed by this application.

CSR is public key plus requested subject name (common name, organization, locality, etc.) signed with corresponding private key. This ensures potential receiver that public key inside this CSR was not tampered during its transmission.

This screen contains informations about issued or imported X.509 certificate. Certificate contains subject\'s (owner\'s) public key with several additional information all together signed with private key of certificate authority. Additional information contains X.500 names of subject and issuer (authority), validity date interval and serial number.

Serial number is unique identifier of certificate assigned by certificate authority. No two different certificates sharing the same serial number signed by the same authority should exist.

Certificate may also contain several extensions - additional informations such as intended usage or flag indicating if this is authority certificate used for signing other certificates.

On this screen you can import keys, certificates and certificate requests into this application. Every imported object is compared to existing records (due to its public key part) and appended to existing record if possible or to newly created record otherwise. You can import objects from file or from textual PEM representation in clipboard. Duplicities of objects are avoided. Import supports following file formats:
• public or private RSA or DSA keys in PEM format only
• X.509 certificates in DER or PEM format
• X.509 certificate signing requests (CSRs) in PEM format
• PKCS#12 keys and certificate bundle, can handle arbitrary number of records inside single bundle.
